caption_original: Environment and Climate Change Canada is pleased to announce the 500th Ecological Gift in Ontario. Sandra Nelles generously donated a conservation easement over 38 hectares of her rural residential property to the Oak Ridges Moraine Land Trust that was certified through the Ecological Gifts Program. The conservation easement was specifically designed for her property and included protection zones to preserve forested areas that contain Butternut—a species of tree endangered in Canada—and zones for continued farming. Ms. Nelles retains ownership of the property, while restricting future development and protecting the ecological features of the land. http://ow.ly/Ej4d303GrZa http://ow.ly/H6se303Gs3l
caption_cleaned: Environment and Climate Change Canada is pleased to announce the th Ecological Gift in Ontario. Sandra Nelles generously donated a conservation easement over hectares of her rural residential property to the Oak Ridges Moraine Land Trust that was certified through the Ecological Gifts Program. The conservation easement was specifically designed for her property and included protection zones to preserve forested areas that contain Butternut—a species of tree endangered in Canada—and zones for continued farming. Ms. Nelles retains ownership of the property, while restricting future development and protecting the ecological features of the land.

caption_original:
Outdoor enthusiasts have long been drawn to the Montagnes Vertes region of southern Quebec. Its hiking trails and ski slopes offer unmatched views of the old-growth forest wilderness. The area is also home to wide-ranging mammals, including moose, bobcats, black bears and fishers, as well as a number of species at risk such as the Bicknell’s Thrush and Canada Warbler.
Environment and Climate Change Canada is working with the Nature Conservancy of Canada and local donors to greatly expand the Montagnes Vertes nature reserve around Mont Sutton to protect important wildlife habitat while continuing public access to the area’s natural beauty. http://ow.ly/GIfM303GsYE

caption_original: They are maybe beautiful but did you know that Mute Swans are very large and powerful birds, and can be capable of aggression? They can cause serious injury to people and pets. Attacks can occur on land and water when attempting to feed them, or after entering their territories. Be careful! Do not approach them during the breeding or brood-rearing seasons. http://ow.ly/wDml302WHA5

caption_original:
Did you know that the Cap Tourmente and Lac Saint Francois National Wildlife Areas in Quebec are designated as wetlands of international importance under the RAMSAR Convention? 
The Cap Tourmente wildlife area was the first site to receive this prestigious designation in North America in 1981. The benefits of wetlands are numerous: they filter our water and limit floods and erosion. They also provide feeding, breeding and nursery habitat for many species. It’s one of the most productive natural habitats on the planet. Let’s protect them!
http://ow.ly/1DMo3034yov

Electricity as an alternative fuel for transportation is already a reality in Canada. The availability of vehicles and charging stations continues to increase. With Budget 2016, the Government of Canada will invest $16.4 million to support the installation of up to 70 fast-charging units for electric vehicles.

The Canada-U.S. Great Lakes Public Forum is a unique opportunity for people on both sides of the border—Indigenous people, scientists, academics, government, community leaders and youth—to come together to share ideas on the most important issues facing the Great Lakes today. It is also a time to celebrate everything that makes our Great Lakes so great.
